awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The role of compensation in the evolution of ornaments
awd_abstract_narration:
Evolution is responsible for many bizarre and showy physical characteristics (i.e. ornaments) in males, but how they remain reliable indicators of male quality remains controversial. Current hypotheses indicate that ornaments are costly to their bearers, however studies testing for decreased locomotor performance or decreased survival or reproductive success (i.e. Darwinian fitness) as a result of ornaments have been inconclusive. For large ornaments, selection should favor evolution of traits and behavior that offset costs of ornaments, thus concealing their true costs. Stalk-eyed flies provide an ideal model system to test for costs and tradeoffs related to male ornamentation due to their exaggerated head morphology, with eyes displaced at the end of long stalks. These flies exhibit considerable variation in muscle and wing size, compensatory traits that may offset the inertial effects of eye stalks on flight performance. This research incorporates biomechanical and flight performance experiments to characterize compensatory ability in relation to ornament size, and determine how the interaction of ornaments and compensatory traits impact flies' ability to evade predators and reproduce. The proposed research has the potential to significantly revise our understanding of how exaggerated traits evolve and also improve our understanding of biomechanical compensation for ornaments and inform bio-inspired engineering efforts such as miniature drones. This research will provide technical training and professional development to a post-doctoral scholar, a technician and graduate and undergraduate students. Outreach efforts at both campuses will provide STEM education to elementary students and training to K-12 educators.

This research employs a novel theoretical and empirical approach to assess the costs of ornaments by considering how compensatory ability in relation to relative ornament size affects the interaction between viability and fecundity. Three distinct avenues of research will be integrated to achieve this goal. First, using species of stalk-eye flies within the family Diopsidae, patterns of correlated evolution between eye stalks and compensatory traits will reveal the macroevolutionary consequences of selection and test the hypothesis that relative ornament size will be positively correlated with the relative size of compensatory traits within and across species. Second, a series of flight performance, maneuverability and predator-avoidance experiments will test the hypothesis that relative compensatory ability predicts viability costs. Finally, a series of mesocosm experiments, where predation and competition interact, will test whether investment in ornamentation versus investment in compensatory traits offers different means to the same fitness end in stalk-eyed flies; the mesocosm experiments will assess the reproductive consequences of viability costs associated with under-compensating for large ornamentation compared to the viability advantages associated with over-compensating for small ornamentation.

por.por_cntn:
Sexual selection in biology is responsible for many bizarre and elaborate male 'ornaments', for example antlers in deer and elk and plumage in birds; but, how these 'ornaments' remain reliable indicators of male quality remains controversial. Even though the prevailing hypotheses indicate that ornaments are costly to their bearers, selection should favor compensatory traits that offset costs associated with ornaments. Stalk-eyed flies provide an ideal model system to test for costs and tradeoffs related to male ornamentation because all species in this extraordinary family display exaggerated head morphology, with eyes displaced at the end of long stalks. These eye stalks impart costs on flight performance, particularly through increased mass and moment of inertia, which should impact maneuverability and flight performance. This project sought to characterize the patterns of correlated evolution between eye stalks and compensatory traits, such as thorax and wing size; and determine how these compensatory traits offset the costs of eye stalks to preserve flight performance. Flies with relatively small thoraces and wings, with respect to the span of their eye stalks, would be 'under-compensating' for the flight performance costs associated with bearing long eye stalks; whereas flies with relatively large thoraces and wings would be 'over-compensating', and therefore possess an advantage during flight-related behaviors.

However, the relationship between costly eye stalks and compensatory traits is obscured by the timeline of flies' sexual maturity, which occurs over the course of 4 weeks through the growth of reproductive tissues. Thus, traits that compensate for the flight-performance costs of eye stalks may also be subject to changes in mass associated with sexual maturation over time. Indeed, age matters! In all experiments conducted, body mass increased across age in adult female and male stalk-eyed flies. Flies' body mass exhibited a pattern of logarithmic growth, which consisted of a sharp 48% increase during the first week, then gradually increased another 37% over the following 7 weeks. All flies increased abdominal mass across age, consistent with the growth of reproductive tissues associated with sexual maturation. However, thorax mass also increased with age, which preserved the thorax-to-body mass ratio. Maximal flight performance was associated with thorax mass and increased with age even though flies became heavier, as the investment into the thorax compensated for the overall increase in body mass across age. Thus, older flies -flies with greater thorax mass- were able to produce greater wingbeat frequency and wing velocity, which increased their maximal flight performance.

Age-related variation in muscle is not well-documented in adult insects, as most developmental studies focus on changes across juvenile stages and regard the adult stage as a terminus of development. Nonetheless, stalk-eyed flies' increase in thorax mass across age was due to increased muscle mass. Flies from a treatment group that was prevented from flying developed less thorax muscle than flies which were allowed to fly. Thus, there is a 'training effect' that accompanies the underlying developmental mechanisms that regulate the growth of thoracic muscle tissue. Abdomen growth reflects the expected resource investment into reproductive (non-lipid) tissues. Interestingly, flies which were allowed to fly developed greater abdomen tissue mass than flies that were restricted from flight. The prolonged sexual maturation of adult stalk-eyed flies is generally peculiar, and presumably limited by how fast the reproductive tissues can grow. Although compensatory mechanisms (e.g. thoracic muscle) do not develop without associated investment costs, the age-related development of thoracic muscle does not appear to compete for allocation of resources with abdomen tissues -that is, the trajectory of abdomen tissue growth is not impacted by the growth of thoracic muscle.

Investment into the reproductive tissues of the abdomen during sexual maturation is compensated by investment into the thorax in order to maintain and/or improve flight performance as flies become heavier with age. Thus, flight performance appears associated with morphological compensation, specifically the growth of the thorax and flight musculature which facilitates the improvement in wing velocity. While our initial predictions for this project suggest that fitness would be influenced by relative compensatory traits, these findings indicate that the time-histories of growth and development of locomotor performance are critical for evaluating the effects of morphological compensation. An individual may be an 'under-compensator' early in adult life, but then later grow into an 'over-compensator'; and, young and old adult flies may be under different predation and selective pressures as they develop muscle mass and increase flight capacity.

This project provided opportunities for research participation, training in laboratory skills, development of analytical skills, research stipends, and training and opportunities in science communication for undergraduate and graduate students, which included members of underrepresented groups.
